GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Alloimmunization is defined as an immune response to foreign antigens after exposure to genetically different cells or tissues.
Blood loss occurring outside menstrual periods.
Hemoperitoneum (sometimes also hematoperitoneum) is the presence of blood in the peritoneal cavity.
High levels of androgens in females.
Abnormally increased secretion and discharge of sebum.
Excessive body hair in women on parts of the body where hair is normally absent or minimal.
A disorder of the skin caused by inflammation of the skin glands and hair follicles. A form found chiefly in adolescents and marked by pimples especially on the face.

A skin condition that is marked by dark discoloration and velvety thickening of the skin especially of body folds or creases (as of the armpit, groin, or neck) and that is often associated with obesity, insulin resistance, hormonal irregularity, or medication use but may rarely occur as a sign of cancer (as of the stomach or liver).
Abnormal absence or suppression of menses.
Flushing is to become markedly red in the face and often other areas of the skin, from various physiological conditions.
Vaginal dryness is the result of decreased levels of estrogen.
A whitish viscid discharge from the vagina resulting from inflammation or congestion of the mucous membrane.

Genital ulcers, defined as single or multiple vesicular, ulcerative or erosive lesions of the genital tract, with or without inguinal lymphadenopathy, should lead to consideration of sexually transmitted infection.
The primary sore of syphilis, a painless indurated, eroded papule, occurring at the site of entry of the infection.
Of, relating to, being, or brought forth by premature birth.

High-risk HPV can cause normal cells to become abnormal. These abnormal cells can lead to cancer over time. High-risk HPV most often affects cells in the cervix, but it can also cause cancer in the vagina, vulva, anus, penis, mouth, and throat.
Vegetation shown on an ultrasound image.
Homogenous mass shown on an ultrasound image.
It is a pelvis in which one or more of its diameters is reduced so that it interferes with the normal mechanism of labour.
Following childbirth or the birth of young.
Hypokalemia is a low level of potassium (K+) in the blood serum.
Hyperkalemia is an elevated level of potassium (K+) in the blood.
Pulmonary edema is fluid accumulation in the tissue and air spaces of the lungs.
There is no perceived pulse to a member.

Livedo reticularis is a common skin finding consisting of a mottled reticulated vascular pattern that appears as a lace-like purplish discoloration of the skin. The discoloration is caused by swelling of the venules owing to obstruction of capillaries by small blood clots.
A bounding pulse signifies high pulse pressure. It may be due to low peripheral resistance, increased cardiac output, increased stroke volume or decreased distensibility of the arterial system.
Jugular vein distention (JVD) occurs when the pressure inside the vena cava increases and appears as a bulge running down the right side of a personâ€™s neck.
The abdominojugular reflux (AJR) sign is useful in diagnosing right ventricular failure, but is often performed and interpreted incorrectly.
The presence of an abdominal murmur may reflect the existence of an aneurysm of the abdominal aorta or a narrowing of the renal arteries.
Abnormal increase in breast volume in men.
Dry skin is skin that has lost its protective fatty layer and becomes dehydrated.
Abnormal increase in plasma prolactin concentration.
A primary adrenal insufficiency caused by a sudden defective production of adrenal steroids.
Hypocalcemia is an abnormal drop in the level of calcium in the blood.
Thrombocytosis is a condition in which there is an excessive number of platelets in the blood.

Bone marrow aplasia refers to those hematologic conditions that are caused by a marked reduction and/or defect in the pluripotent or committed stem cells, or the failure of the bone marrow microenvironment to support hematopoiesis.

Telangiectasias, also known as spider veins, are small dilated blood vessels that can occur near the surface of the skin or mucous membranes, measuring between 0.5 and 1 millimeter in diameter. These dilated blood vessels can develop anywhere on the body but are commonly seen on the face around the nose, cheeks and chin.
Iron overload or hemochromatosis indicates accumulation of iron in the body from any cause.
The patient is in the process of rejection of his transplant, which corresponds to the destruction of the graft transplanted into an organism, due to an immune response directed against him.
During an upper digestive hemorrhage (UDH), the bleeding occurs upstream of the Treitz ligament (oesophagus, stomach and duodenum).
In a lower digestive hemorrhage (LDH), blood loss originates downstream from the Treitz ligament (small intestine, colon, rectum and anus).
The patient has wide purple colored stretch marks on their abdomen.
The patient's stomach contents flow back into the oesophagus resulting in unpleasant symptoms such as heartburn and the taste of acid in the mouth.
A CT scan shows evidence of bleeding from the adrenal glands. This is a strong indicator of an adrenal crisis requiring immediate emergency treatment!
Hyperpigmentation is the darkening of an area of skin or nails caused by increased melanin.
Echocardiography has revealed cardiac valve vegetations. A cardiac vegetation is an abnormal growth on the valves of the heart that is typically made up of fibrin and platelets.
The patient has deposition of calcium in lumps under the skin.

Digital clubbing is a clinically descriptive term, referring to the bulbous uniform swelling of the soft tissue of the terminal phalanx of a digit (fingers or toes) with subsequent loss of the normal angle between the nail and the nail bed.

The face has a rounded moon-like appearance due to fat deposits on the side of the face. This is often associated with Cushing's syndrome (elevated serum cortisol) or long term corticosteroid treatment.
The patient has a hump on the upper back between the shoulder blades in an area of fat accumulation on the back of the neck. This is sometimes referred to as a "buffalo hump".
Erythema nodosum is an inflammatory condition characterized by inflammation of the fat cells under the skin, resulting in tender red nodules or lumps that are usually seen on both shins.

Frontal bossing is the development of an unusually pronounced forehead which may also be associated with a heavier than normal brow ridge. It is caused by enlargement of the frontal bone, often in conjunction with abnormal enlargement of other facial bones, skull, mandible, and bones of the hands and feet.
Fungemia is the presence of fungi or yeasts in the blood.
The patient has spontaneous flow of milk from the breast, unassociated with childbirth or nursing. Galactorrhea can take place as a result of dysregulation of certain hormones.
Ground-glass opactities seen on high resolution CT scan.
A CT scan finding that indicates a partial filling of air spaces in the lungs by exudate or transudate, as well as interstitial thickening or partial collapse of lung alveoli.

A medical condition in which spasm of arteries causes episodes of reduced blood flow. The fingers are typically involved. The episodes result in the affected part turning white and then blue. In this patient, it is likely due to an underlying condition.

The patient has acrochorda (skin tags), small benign tumors that forms primarily in areas where the skin forms creases, such as the neck, armpit and groin. They may also occur on the face, usually on the eyelids.

Koilonychia, also known as spoon nails is a nail disease that can be a sign of anemia, especially iron-deficiency anemia. It refers to abnormally thin nails (usually of the hand) which have lost their convexity, becoming flat or even concave in shape.
Sclerodactyly is a localized thickening and tightness of the skin of the fingers or toes.
The patient has damaged and sore skin on their fingers and toes.

Oral examination has revealed the presence of apthous ulcers. These are recurrent round or oval sores inside the mouth on an area where the skin is not tightly bound to the underlying bone, such as on the inside of the lips and cheeks or underneath the tongue.
Decreased diffusion capacity of the lungs
The ability of oxygen to travel from the alveoli in the lungs to the bloodstream is reduced due to underlying lung disease.

A collection of immune cells known as macrophages have aggregated to form an area of inflammation (visualized under a microscope) known as a granuloma. Granulomas form when the immune system attempts to wall off substances it perceives as foreign but is unable to eliminate.

A collection of immune cells known as macrophages have aggregated to form an area of inflammation (visualized under a microscope) known as a granuloma. Granulomas form when the immune system attempts to wall off substances it perceives as foreign but is unable to eliminate.
CT scan has revealed a swollen and irritated pericardium (inflammation of the sac that the heart lies in).
A tumor of the Pituitary gland (in the brain) has been detected. Depending on the size of the tumor, it may present with visual field defects due to compression of the optic chiasm.
The patient has a very tender, red, swollen 1st metatarsophalangeal joint (the joint between the foot and big toe). This is known as podagra and is a common manifestation of acute gout.
Prognathism is an extension or bulging out (protrusion) of the lower jaw.
The patient has abnormal protrusion or displacement of the eyes.
Excess fibrous connective has accumulated in the lungs leading to thickening of the walls.
Pulmonary hemorrhage is an acute bleeding from the lungs, upper respiratory tract, the trachea and the alveoli.
Spirometry shows a restrictive lung disease pattern.
The patient has deposits of crystalline uric acid and other substances in cartilage tissue, tendons, and soft tissues.
Chest X-ray has revealed the presence of lung nodules; these are small 'spots' that can represent benign tumors such as granulomas or less commonly malignant cancer.
The patient has abnormally rapid breathing.
The X-ray findings together with the physical examination and overall clinical picture of the patient suggests a diagnosis of an atypical pneumonia.
Blood tests show abnormalities of iron metabolism
Uremia is the condition of having high levels of urea in the blood. Urea is one of the primary components of urine.
Serology has detected the presence of Antinuclear antibodies.
The fluid collected from BAL has revealed a significantly elevated amount of lymphocytes (white blood cells).
Hypertrichosis is an abnormal amount of hair growth over the body.

Blood tests show low levels of Albumin in the blood. Albumin is a protein found in the blood that transports hormones, fatty acids, and other compounds, buffers pH, and maintains oncotic pressure, among other functions.
Physical examination reveals gangrene. Loss of blood supply to the affected areas has led to tissue death which has a dry, purple-blue blackish appearance.
Venous thromboembolism is a condition in which a blood clot forms most often in the deep veins of the leg, groin or arm and travels in the circulation, lodging in the lungs
The patient has tiny blood clots that run vertically under the nails.
The patient's teeth are widely spaced and separated by large gaps.
Patient is experiencing intense amount of pain.
The patient feels like they have pressure in their ears or their ears feel full.
Snoring is the action or fact of making a snorting or grunting sound while asleep, It's caused by Obstructive Sleep Apnea.

Nasal polyps are soft, painless, noncancerous growths on the lining of your nasal passages or sinuses. They hang down like teardrops or grapes. They result from chronic inflammation. They either can be treated with saline spray or surgery.
Nasal findings has been found by a CT.
Post nasal drip is mucus from your nose and it drips harmlessly down the back of your throat, and you swallow it.
The patient's nasal cavity is is inflammed.
Inflamed mucous tissue lining that covers the sinuses.
The patient has unidentified fluids coming from the nose.
The patient experienced a neck injury.
The patient has a swollen neck.
The patient has unidentified fluids coming from the mouth.
Xerostomia means dry mouth, the petients mouth is dry.
The patient's mouth isn't producing saliva that much, causes the patint's mouth to be dry.

Sialolithiasis is the medical term for salivary gland stones. These stones, or calculi, are mostly composed of calcium, but they also contain magnesium, potassium, and ammonium. Your mouth has three salivary glands that can develop stones: parotid, submandibular, sublingual, and minor salivary glands.

A pseudomembrane is a false membrane in the eye or throat that sometimes develops during infections and inflammations. It typically covers the conjunctiva, or the white part of the eyes, and can be very uncomfortable, and a pseudomembrane also usually develops when the patient has Diphtheria.
A Vocal Polyp has hemorrhaged in the patient
A lump in the throat has been found in the patient

Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs. The air sacs may fill with fluid or pus, causing cough with phlegm or pus, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing. A variety of organisms, including bacteria, viruses and fungi, can cause pneumonia.Without treating bacterial pneumonia it can lead to complications like respiratory failure.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a type of respiratory failure characterized by rapid onset of widespread inflammation in the lungs. Symptoms include shortness of breath, rapid breathing, and bluish skin coloration.

Stridor is a high-pitched, wheezing sound caused by disrupted airflow. Stridor may also be called musical breathing or extrathoracic airway obstruction. Airflow is usually disrupted by a blockage in the larynx (voice box) or trachea (windpipe). Stridor affects children more often than adults.
The patient has decreased pitch range and loudness
